Radio Ô¨Çaring and dual radio loud/quiet behaviour in the new
candidate black hole X-ray binary MAXI J1631-472
South African Astronomical Observatory, P.O Box 9, Observatory, 7935, Cape Town, South Africa
Astrophysics, University of Oxford, Denys Wilkinson Building, Keble Road, Oxford OX1 3RH
INAF‚ÄìOsservatorio Astronomico di Brera, via E. Bianchi 46, 23807 Merate (LC), Italy
Department of Astronomy, University of Cape Town, Private Bag X3, Rondebosch 7701, South Africa

Shanghai Astronomical Observatory, Chinese Academy of Sciences,
80 Nandan Road, Shanghai 200030, China

International Centre for Radio Astronomy Research - Curtin University, GPO Box U1987, Perth, WA 6845, Australia

Last updated 2015 May 22; in original form 2013 September 5

We present the results of a weekly monitoring of the new black hole candidate X-ray binary
MAXI J1631-472 carried out with the MeerKAT radio interferometer, the
, and the Monitor of All-sky X-ray Image (

) instrument, during its 2018-
2019 outburst. The source exhibits a number of X-ray states, in particular both high- and
low-luminosity hard states bracketed by extended soft states. Radio Ô¨Çaring is observed shortly
after a transition from hard/intermediate states to the soft state. This is broadly in agreement
with existing empirical models, but its extended duration hints at multiple unresolved Ô¨Çares
and/or jet-ISM interactions. In the hard state radio:X-ray plane, the source is revealed to be
‚Äòradio quiet‚Äô at high luminosities, but to rejoin the ‚Äòstandard‚Äô track at lower luminosities, an
increasingly commonly-observed pattern of behaviour.

X-ray binaries are stellar systems which comprise a normal star
(the donor), usually still undergoing nuclear fusion, and a remnant

of an evolved star, the compact object, which is either a neutron
star or a black hole. In these systems X-ray emission is powered
by the accretion of matter from the donor to the compact object.
Depending on the spectral type of the donor, X-ray binaries are gen-
erally divided up into high mass X-ray binaries (O/B spectral type;

) and low mass X-ray binaries (spectral type later
than A;

). In low mass X-ray binaries (LMXBs), the
compact object, either a neutron star (NS) or a black hole (BH),
accretes matter from the donor through an accretion disc via Roche
Lobe overÔ¨Çow. BH LMXBs are transient in nature, since they spend
a majority of the time in quiescence and occasionally go into out-
burst where the X-ray Ô¨Çux is seen to increase by several orders
of magnitude (Remillard & McClintock 2006). These outbursts can
last from weeks to years (Belloni & Motta 2016). The varying X-ray
emission has an associated radio emission, and these two quantities

are typically correlated in the hard spectral state (Corbel et al. 2000,
2003; Fender 2001; Gallo et al. 2004; Fender & Belloni 2012).

During outbursts, transient BH LMXB usually sample diÔ¨Äerent
states, which are deÔ¨Åned by their X-ray spectral and timing prop-

erties, and which are connected with the properties of the radio jet
(Belloni 2010). At the outset of the outburst, when the X-ray Ô¨Çux is
low (

), the system typically lies in the hard state
and the emission is associated with inverse Compton up-scattering
of seed photons in a coronal region close to the accretion disc (Bel-
loni & Motta 2016). The associated radio emission is typically weak
(

) with a Ô¨Çat spectral index. As the system goes
further into an outburst, the Ô¨Çux rises. At a certain X-ray luminosity
level - which varies in a large range from source to source and from
outburst to outburst for a single source (Tetarenko et al. 2016) - the
system transitions to an intermediate state and then enters the soft
state. In the intermediate state, optically thin relativistic radio jets
can be observed. As the system enters the soft spectral state, the
X-ray emission is thermal, which has been attributed to an optically
thick geometrically thin accretion disc, while the radio emission
decreases as the jet is quenched (Corbel et al. 2001; Coriat et al.
2011). These spectral state changes typically trace out a distinct

path in the hardness-intensity diagram (Yu et al. 2004, 2007; Yu &
Yan 2009; Belloni et al. 2011; Fender & Belloni 2012), which is
associated with a transition from a compact jet to an episodic jet
(Fender et al. 2004).

MAXI J1631-472 was Ô¨Årst detected as a bright X-ray source
by Monitor of All-sky X-ray Image/Gas Slit Camera (

;
Matsuoka et al. 2009) on 21 December 2018, and was initially
mistaken for the X-ray pulsar AX MAXI J1631-4752 (Kobayashi
et al. 2018). Further observations with the BAT instrument on-board
the

; Gehrels et al. 2004)
and Nuclear Spectroscopic Telescope Array (

; Harrison
et al. 2010) revealed that the position of MAXI J1631-472, with
a separation of 8

, is not consistent with that of AX MAXI
J1631-4752. MAXI J1631-472 was therefore classiÔ¨Åed as a new
X-ray transient (Miyasaka et al. 2018). The NuSTAR spectrum
(energy band 3

79 keV) was Ô¨Åt with a blackbody disc temperature
of 1
01 keV and a power-law index of 2

02. The
spectral Ô¨Åtting revealed an iron K-alpha emission line with an
equivalent width of 90 eV, indicating evidence of a reÔ¨Çection
component in the spectrum (Miyasaka et al. 2018). The spectral
properties suggested that MAXI J1631-472 is a binary system with
an accreting black hole detected by

in the soft state. A
radio counterpart was detected at the position consistent with that
from the X-ray observations (Russell et al. 2019).

Since 12 January 2019 (MJD 58495), MAXI J1631-472 has
been monitored with MeerKAT as part of the ThunderKAT Large
Survey Project (Fender et al. 2017). In this manuscript we re-
port on the results of the monitoring of MAXI J1631-472 with
the MeerKAT interferometer, complemented with X-ray data from

. We show the evolution of the radio and X-ray
emission throughout its outburst and provide a physical interpreta-
tion of the dataset. We also compare the behaviour observed with
other known outbursting BH systems.
The paper is structured as follows: in section 2 we describe the obser-
vations and details of the data reduction. In section 3 we present the
results of the two wavebands and highlight some of the interesting
behaviour. In section 4 we summarise our conclusions.
The MeerKAT monitoring of MAXI J1631-472 was performed

weekly, with the observations carried out at a central frequency of
1.28 GHz and bandwidth of 856 MHz. These observations were
taken as part of the

Large Survey Programme on
MeerKAT (Fender et al. 2016). Each observation consists of a 15
minute scan of the target, and a two-minute scan of the phase cal-
ibrator, in this case J1726-5529. The primary calibrator used was
J1939-6342, which was observed at the start of each observation for
5 minutes. We used casa (McMullin et al. 2007) to perform the data
reduction. We performed Ô¨Çagging of radio frequency interference
(RFI), where we removed the Ô¨Årst and last 150 channels (channel
width

209 kHz) of the band. The auto-Ô¨Çagging algorithms, rflag
and tfcrop, were used for subsequent Ô¨Çagging. We then performed
calibration, where the Ô¨Çux density on the primary calibrator was set
using the known model. The phase-only and antenna-based delay
corrections on the primary calibrator were then solved for, then the
bandpass corrections for the primary were then applied. We solved
for the complex gains on the primary and secondary, then proceeded

Flux densities for MAXI J1631-472 were extracted from the
images using PyBDSF (Mohan & RaÔ¨Äerty 2015); these are pre-
sented in Table 1. We were able to extract an in-band spectral index
(

)
at the four brightest epochs using a Ô¨Åt to eight uniformly-spaced
channels across the 856 MHz bandpass. To determine the spectral
index, we performed a least-squares Ô¨Åt using the scipy and curve-
fit module and function, respectively, in python to calculate the
slope and its associated error bar. The results from these Ô¨Åts are
presented in Table 2 and indicate that the source was optically thin
during the times of strongest radio Ô¨Çux density.

The hardness intensity diagram (HID) for MAXI J1631-472 during

the 2018/19 outburst is shown in Fig. 2. Fig. 2 (a) shows the HID
for the full duration of the outburst, with the colour bar representing

a rapid rise in photon Ô¨Çux as it changes from quiescence to peak
Ô¨Çux in roughly 25 days while the spectral state changes from hard
(HR

1.2) during this period. The decline of the
X-ray photon Ô¨Çux occurs while the system is in the soft state, during
which the radio Ô¨Çare is seen to occur (colour-bar in Fig. 2 (c))).

(2

The HID track of MAXI J1631-472 follows a diagonal transi-
tion during the rise of the outburst when the spectral state changes
from hard to soft and is similar to those seen in systems such as GRO
J1655‚Äì40 and XTE J1550‚Äì564 (e.g. Russell et al. 2010; Uttley &
Klein-Wolt 2015). Some systems follow a

‚Äôq‚Äô-shaped
HID pattern where the rise in X-ray Ô¨Çux from quiescence to peak
happens in the hard state and the system changes to intermediate
and then to soft at roughly constant peak Ô¨Çux. The diÔ¨Äerences in
the shapes of the HIDs have been suggested to be due to inclination
angle diÔ¨Äerences, with the ‚Äôq‚Äô-shaped HIDs occurring in low incli-

Mu√±oz-Darias et al. 2013). This suggests
that the orbit of MAXI J1631-472 is possibly highly inclined.
particle acceleration (see for example Bright et al.
2020). Such emission can persist for many months, fading slowly,

which is the most likely explanation for the persistent low level ra-
dio emission throughout the soft state. This component, originating
in ejecta completely separated from the core may potentially con-
tribute to the radio Ô¨Çux measured from the source after its return to
the hard state (see further discussion in section 3.4).

use the single-frequency estimates of the physical parameters from
Fender & Bright (2019) (their equations 28 ‚Äì 31). For a distance
of 5 kpc, at a peak Ô¨Çux density of 40 mJy at 1.4 GHz, we Ô¨Ånd a
corresponding physical radius at peak of

(Fender & Bright 2019). These es-
timates are reasonable in the context of other X-ray binaries and
rather typical of a low-mass X-ray binary (and notably consider-

the spectral index measurements (Table 2) indicate that the source
may well have been optically thin throughout the phase of brightest
radio emission. In addition, as noted above, this is unlikely to have
been a single event. Therefore the energy estimates remain highly

The strongest radio emission from MAXI J1631-472 occurred
shortly after the transition from the intermediate to the soft X-
ray state. This is broadly in agreement with the uniÔ¨Åed picture put
forward in Fender et al. (2004). The three weeks or more of bright
radio emission hints at multiple Ô¨Çaring events, since Ô¨Çares from
X-ray binaries tend to evolve on shorter timescales (e.g. Fender &
Bright 2019), and these shorter timescale radio Ô¨Çares may them-
selves be the superposition of multiple events which can only be
discriminated at mm/IR frequencies (e.g. Tetarenko et al. 2017) or
with Very Long Baseline Interferometry (VLBI; e.g. Miller-Jones
et al. 2019). There may also be a contribution from physically sepa-
rated ejecta which are fading only slowly due to jet-ISM interactions

BH LMXBs in the hard state are known to show a correlation
between the X-ray and radio luminosities. The ‚Äòstandard‚Äô correlation
between the radio and X-ray emission in the black hole hard state
takes a non-linear form

(Corbel et al. 2000; Gallo
et al. 2003, 2014; Espinasse & Fender 2018). A second population
of BH LMXBs exists, the co-called ‚Äòradio-faint‚Äô systems, which
have a smaller ratio of radio to X-ray luminosity and may have a
steeper relationship between the radio and X-ray emission of the
form

(Coriat et al. 2011; Cao et al. 2014). Several
suggestions have been made to explain the physical origin of the two
tracks which include variations in the magnetic Ô¨Åeld strength of the
jet (Casella & Pe‚Äôer 2009), diÔ¨Äerences in the distribution of matter

The radio/X-ray correlation plot which includes the hard state BH LMXBs shown with the grey Ô¨Ålled squares from the compiled database by
Bahramian et al. (2018). The hard state measurements for MAXI J1631-472 are shown using diÔ¨Äerent distances: 2 kpc (purple Ô¨Ålled circles), 5 kpc (red open
squares), 8 kpc (orange crosses).

in the inner accretion disc (Meyer-Hofmeister & Meyer 2014) and
diÔ¨Äerences in the inclination angles of the binary systems (Motta
et al. 2018). Gallo et al. (2018), however, suggest, from a statistical
viewpoint, that the two populations are indistinct. The BH LMXB
H1743-322 has been shown to be ‚Äòradio quiet‚Äô at high luminosities,
but to return to the ‚Äòstandard‚Äô track at an X-ray luminosity between

(Coriat et al. 2011). Motta et al. (2018) have
argued that this is probably a general property of all ‚Äòradio quiet‚Äô
sources, i.e. there is only a single radio:X-ray correlation at low
X-ray luminosities.

Fig. 3 shows the radio/X-ray correlation plot which includes
measurements of known BH LMXBs using the compiled measure-
ments in Bahramian et al. (2018) and hard state measurements of
MAXI J1631-472 presented in this work at 5 kpc. The 1.28 GHz
radio measurements from MeerKAT were converted to 5 GHz as-
suming a Ô¨Çat spectral index for comparison with measurements
presented in Bahramian et al. (2018). Note that we do not cur-
rently have any reliable distance estimates for the source, so we
consider distances of 2, 5 and 8 kpc. For the entire range of dis-
tances, it appears that the earlier hard state measurements trace out
the ‚Äòradio-quiet‚Äô region while the three measurements taken later
during the decline of the X-ray Ô¨Çux seem to be more consistent
‚Äòradio-loud‚Äô track. MAXI J1631-472 therefore becomes another

source for which the switch from high-luminosity ‚Äòradio quiet‚Äô to
lower-luminosity ‚Äòstandard track‚Äô evolution is observed, similar to
systems such as H1743-322 (Coriat et al. 2011), Swift J1753.5-
0127 (Plotkin et al. 2017), XTE J1752-223 (Ratti et al. 2012) and
XTE J1659-152 (Ratti et al. 2012). As noted above (section 3.3) we
cannot rule out some contribution from fading ejecta, launched at

the earlier hard-to-soft state transition, to the radio emission in the
hard state. Examining Figure 1 in detail we can see that there was a
small rise in the radio emission of approximately 12% between two
consecutive observations around the time of the transition back to
the intermediate state (around MJD 58630), which likely indicates
the re-activation of the compact hard state jet. In the case of MAXI
J1820+070 this re-activated core jet dominates the fading emission
from the jet (Bright et al. 2020), and the slight re-brightening noted
above suggests this is also the case for MAXI J1631-472. We note
that regardless of the physical origin, the observational phenomenon
of sources returning to the ‚Äòstandard track‚Äô at moderately low lu-
minosities is now well established. We cannot conclusively rule out
this being due to fading ejecta in every case, but it seems unlikely.

We have presented radio and X-ray observations of the newly-
discovered BH LMXB candidate, MAXI J1631-472, during its
2018-2019 outburst. The radio data were taken at a central frequency
of 1.28 GHz with the MeerKAT interferometer as part of the Thun-
derKAT Large Survey Project. We used publicly available data from

to analyse its X-ray behaviour, where we Ô¨Ånd that
MAXI J1631-472 undergoes various state transitions throughout the
outburst. We have investigated the quasi-simultaneous MeerKAT
and

observations to explore the radio/X-ray correlation. A
prolonged period of radio Ô¨Çaring begins at the transition to the
second-observed soft state, and probably originates in multiple
Ô¨Çare-ejection events and possibly additional jet-ISM interactions.
A comparison of the contemporaneous hard-state X-ray and radio
measurements of MAXI J1631-472 with those from other BH sys-
tems reveals an evolution from the ‚Äôradio quiet‚Äô to ‚Äòradio loud‚Äô tracks
as the X-ray luminosity decreases.
